title: East London Cage Fighter From Britain'S Biggest Robbery Shot In His Kitchen And Paralysed
summary: A former cagefighter, Paul Allen, was shot in his kitchen in Woodford Green, Redbridge, and was left paralyzed. The intention was to kill him, and three men are accused of plotting to murder him. The shooting was heard throughout Woodford, and neighbors found Allen with a towel pressed to his neck and struggling to breathe. The gun used was a Glock 9mm, and DNA was matched to Kelly and Louis Ahearne on a nearby fence panel. Allen is a career criminal who was convicted of Britain's largest cash robbery in 2006. The defendants traveled from Woolwich, through the Blackwall Tunnel, to the victim's new home in Malvern Drive as part of the planning and execution of the conspiracy.

title: Norrie Wins To Reach Delray Beach Open Last Eight
summary: British tennis player Cameron Norrie advances to the quarter-finals of the Delray Beach Open in Florida. Norrie, the 2022 winner, beat French fifth seed Arthur Rinderknech in a challenging match. He will face either Michael Mmoh or Alex Michelsen in the next round.

title: The London Burger Restaurant Named The Uk'S Best Which Started Out As A Market Stall
summary: Black Bear Burger, a London-based restaurant with locations in Camden and other boroughs, was named the UK's best burger at the National Burger Awards 2025. The company started as a market stall and has grown to include multiple locations. The award-winning Miso Bacon Burger is made with high-quality ingredients and was chosen from among 16 finalists.

title: Mum Would Want Me To Talk About Cancer - Mead
summary: Arsenal and England winger Beth Mead supports a public health campaign to eliminate cervical cancer by 2040, inspired by her late mother who passed away from ovarian and cervical cancer. The campaign, called 'defend your tomorrow', aims to raise awareness during the north London derby at Emirates Stadium. Mead also discusses the growing rivalry between Arsenal and Tottenham women's teams.

title: Jordan Group Buys London Irish Out Of Administration
summary: Eddie Jordan's consortium, 'The Jordan Associates', bought London Irish Rugby Club out of administration, aiming for a swift return to top-flight competition. The club's playing base will remain in west London, but the new owners have not specified the exact location. Jordan was diagnosed with a form of cancer in December.

title: Jackson Out For Six Weeks With Hamstring Injury
summary: Chelsea forward Nicolas Jackson is out for six weeks due to a hamstring injury, leaving the team without a recognized number nine. This could impact the team's performance in the Premier League as they face Brighton again in the league on Friday.

title: Wife Calls To Ban Gambling Ads After Husband'S £85K Debt
summary: Tracy, an affected other lead at the charity GamLearn, advocates for a ban on gambling ads due to her husband's £85,000 debt and mental health struggles. Haringey Council, having the fourth most licensed gambling premises in London, supports this initiative and is pushing for a national ban on gambling advertising. The council aims to restrict gambling advertising's negative influence on individuals and families.

title: The Village Divided By Heathrow Airport Expansion
summary: The construction of a third runway at Heathrow Airport is causing controversy in the village of Harmondsworth, located in the London borough of Hillingdon. Some residents welcome the decision for economic growth, while others are saddened by the potential destruction of their birthplace and historical sites, including Commonwealth War graves. The expansion would also put the village closer to the Public Safety Zone, causing distress for many.

summary: A man was tragically killed in a pop-up urinal accident in Soho, London. His family is seeking answers and closure, expressing frustration with the slow investigation process. The incident highlights the challenges and dangers of urban infrastructure maintenance.

summary: Thames Water is under investigation for not completing over 100 environmental schemes in Greenwich and other boroughs, which includes upgrades to sewage treatment works and reducing wastewater spillages. This delay may mean the company has breached its license and could face penalties.

title: Waste To Pay Officers We Can'T Sack, Says Met Chief
summary: Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Mark Rowley criticized the High Court's ruling that the force cannot dismiss officers who fail vetting due to lack of opportunity for defense. Twenty-nine officers are on special leave, costing millions of pounds, and the Met plans to appeal the decision. The issue of dismissing unfit officers has been a problem for over 20 years due to Home Office regulation failures.

title: Thousands Left Without Water After Major Pipe Bursts
summary: A pipe burst in Crystal Palace has left thousands of homes and businesses in south London without water or with reduced supply, particularly affecting SE19, SE20, SE23, SE26, SE27, and SW16 postcodes. Thames Water is working to restore water and fix the pipe, with bottled water delivered to priority services. Flooding at Crystal Palace Pumping Station is adding to supply problems.

title: Pair Deny Damaging Darwin'S Westminster Abbey Grave
summary: Two pensioners, Alyson Lee and Di Bligh, denied damaging Charles Darwin's grave in Westminster Abbey by spraying it with orange chalk paint. The writing, "1.5 is dead", refers to attempts to limit global warming to 1.5C and reduce the impact of climate change. The church does not anticipate permanent damage.

title: Three Girls Sexually Assaulted Near Clapham Common
summary: A man has been arrested for sexually assaulting three girls near Clapham Common in Lambeth. The incidents occurred on January 8 and 23, and police are asking for other victims to come forward.

title: Rogue Officers On Paid Leave 'Could Cost Millions'
summary: The Metropolitan Police Commissioner has expressed concern over the cost of keeping officers on paid leave, which could reach tens of millions of pounds a year due to a High Court ruling. The force is preparing an appeal to be able to sack officers who have had their vetting clearance removed. There are currently 29 officers on paid leave and 96 who have been sacked or resigned. The commissioner has been lobbying the Home Office for action, as the Met faces significant cuts to frontline services, although not on the scale previously feared.

title: Little Simz Curating 'Epic' Meltdown Festival At Southbank Centre
summary: Rapper Little Simz is curating the Meltdown festival at Southbank Centre in Southwark. The 11-day festival will feature live performances and workshops, with the full line-up to be announced in Spring. Little Simz has previously curated a Tate Modern Late event and played Glastonbury's Pyramid Stage.

title: The North London Nursery School Where Kids Can Be Read To 'Whenever They Pick Up A Book'
summary: Kate Greenaway Nursery School and Children's Centre in Islington has maintained its outstanding status, with pupils demonstrating excellent behavior and a love for reading. The school's curriculum, personal development provision, and support for children with special educational needs are commended. The new Ofsted grading system, which provides rich, granular insight, will be introduced in the 2025 autumn term.

title: Met Police Chief Hits Out At Middle-Class Drug Users Putting Kids 'In Coffins' To Put Cocaine On Their Table
summary: London's police chief criticizes middle-class drug users for fueling youth violence and exploitation through their cocaine habits. The Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Mark Rowley highlighted the link between drug purchasing and violent crime, stating that kids are often used to deliver drugs, putting them at risk of gang involvement and violence. Data shows London has the highest rate of cocaine use in England and Wales, with the capital consuming 23 kilos of cocaine a day. The issue comes as London sees a decrease in teenage homicides, which the Mayor's office attributes to the Violence Reduction Unit (VRU) set up in 2019.

summary: A person died after being hit by a train near Barnes station in Richmond upon Thames, causing significant disruptions to train services. The incident is not being treated as suspicious.

The express bus service has seen an increase in journeys, with TfL planning to launch Superloop 2 by the end of the year.

title: The North London Council Spending £100K A Day On Temporary Housing - 33K Households Wait For A Home
summary: Brent Council in London is spending £100,000 a day on temporary housing due to a growing demand for social housing, with 33,000 households on the waiting list. The rapid population growth and limited social housing supply have resulted in increased costs for the council. The council is urging the government to intervene with additional support and policy changes to tackle the housing crisis.

title: South London Restaurant Announces Shock Closure After 12 Years - Owners Tease Who Is Taking Over
summary: Forza Win, an Italian restaurant in Camberwell, is closing after 12 years. The closure has been met with disappointment from patrons. The owners will focus on expanding their sister business, Forza Wine. A new tenant has already been found for the space, but details have not been disclosed.

summary: A man was stabbed in Shepherd's Bush in broad daylight, resulting in a negative societal impact for the borough of Hammersmith and Fulham.

title: Real Reason Ross Kemp Left Eastenders As He Makes Grant Mitchell Comeback
summary: Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for the show's 40th anniversary. He will support his brother Phil Mitchell amid his mental health battle. Fans can expect to see his return scenes in February.

title: Full Dates Heathrow Airport Staff Striking In February - With Threat To Extend Made
summary: Cleaning staff at Heathrow Airport, located in the London borough of Hillingdon, have threatened to strike over low wages. The staff, employed by facilities services firm OCS, claim they are not being paid the real living wage. The strike is scheduled for February 25-28, and could escalate if a satisfactory pay offer is not made. Heathrow Airport has confirmed that if the strike proceeds, it will not impact airport operations.

title: £16 Spray Is Giving Shoppers 'Best Night'S Sleep Ever'
summary: A £16 pillow spray called This Works Deep Sleep Pillow Spray is gaining popularity among Amazon shoppers for improving sleep. It has positive reviews from multiple retailers and contains a calming lavender scent. The product is available in London at various stores.
